reviews.review_text: PROTOTYPE 2 – REVIEW

Recomended!  The Good: Feel like the most powerful being, unleash devastating powers on the world, use everything, destroy all and everything. This feeling doesn't go away fast, it feels great!  The gameplay is great!  Using the tendrills is fantastic!  I actually liked the story New game+  The Bad: I see a lot of people saying they have issues. I haven't had a single bug, or crash. It took me 13 hours to go through the story and unlock everything (on normal), feels to short...  The Ugly: James Heller is a very cool guy, yet I'd like to see more of his background known.  Some things are copied from the previous game. Cheesy oneliners.

Great game, solid 10 hour campaign, fun to excessivly and accidentally slaughter everything *in a game*, shows humankinds true nature as monsters. Only has so many negative reviews because it doesn't work with AMD,  Ahhh the time when we reviewed games on how good they were. Recommended if you love action 7/10.
This is my fevorite game of all time..great powers..flying was great ..they need to make more of these games. 10/10

WOULD NOT RECOMMEND FOR AMD. Luckily this game was gifted to me, the storyline itself is very cool, and if it weren't for unsupported AMD users I would recommend this game to anyone. The first game was addicting but, even an hour in to this game, it is UNPLAYABLE.

Now, in my opinion, Prototype 1 is superior to this one in alot of ways, it was one of the best open world games I have played, hacking and slashing your way through New York was really fun. Now, Prototype 2 is a really good and fun game in my opinion. The gameplay is pretty much the same with the controls etc, but the game takes away some freedom you had in prototype 1. And I've heard alot of negative responses because the main character is black, but I personally don't mind. I like this change. The story can also be a bit better, they shouldn't have taken the revenge thingy again, but it SOMEWHAT fits in, if there is going to be another Prototype game, it needs some better lore. Overall, the game is worth playing, and very addicting at that. 7.5/10

It's different to the first game - better, worse? Just different. There are not as many powers in this game, but then the first one had ones you'd never use. Running around the city in some ways is easier in this game, but I had more fun doing it in the first one - but the fiddly bits of running up buildings have gone, which makes this one better. Obviously the graphics are better in this one.  The protagonist in this one seems to be badly written, and fills too many stereotype boxes. It's not quite blacksploitation, but something about 'Hell ♥♥♥♥in' yeah!' doesn't sit quite right with me. Now if someone can tell me what the hell happened to Alex Mercer between the first game and this one, that'd be great.

Gameplay, as expected, 10/10, totally satisfied about it, bought the game only because of that.  The rest is... ugh. Story: Too dull and straight forward, really predictable, just like 'go there and blow everything up' Memories: Unlike on the first one you can't figure out much about backstory only with them, they just focus on information over objectives and plans that you are meant to frustrate. Alex Mercer: While what he wants to do certainly sounds like something Alex could possibly do how he executes his plans, how he talks, how his allies are and his cleverness, are all inconsistent to the legendary Alex Mercer from Prototype 1, he was just turned into a cliche villain that actually doesn't have much participation as one would expect. I repeat, bought this game for the gameplay, because, apart from graphics, it's the only thing better than it was in the first title.

This is a great game. Your basically a superhero running around a city. The city itself is similar to that of gta3, pushing 4. There's plenty of people on the ground, cars don't really appear, as everything is in a military lock down. You the hero basically run around running up buildings and leap / glide around the world. The level system works well letting you pit skill points where you see fit.  The story is good, your piecing together events from memories of those you consue  Early on the game will bug out when using the claws, there's a affinity bodge that works well and once done you can set the game back to all cores.  I love it

It's like the first Prototype, but with more skills, weapons, enemies, etc. It's still the pure, endless massacre and you are still playing the super strong ultra-mutant! So if you liked the first Prototype you'll also like this one also.
This game is amazing. It more focused on gameplay and story compared to graphics and isnt really compatible with AMD GPU's. Strongly recommend AMD users not to play.

After playing the first one on pc, I was relieved to see that they had help resolve a lot of the frustration from the 'bad' port to pc. Definitely worth it to give it a shot. So far I've spent almost 3 hours playing and have only completed 11% of the Story . I am liking those numbers.
This game is a great stress reliever. Had a bad day at work? Do you feel like everyone's talking smack about you behind your back? Load this puppy up and take out some aggression.

This game is the junkfood of sandbox action adventures.  The graphics are nothing to be astounded by, alongside the boring, repetitive enviroment. Nor should you think about the story and it's baby-eating evil cast. On those merits, this game would be terrible.  BUT, what this game does well, is let you run around the streets of New York as an unstoppable monster, fighting both infected and military enemies with incerdible ease. Though the fighting can be a bit fiddly, it's fun, frantic and empowering.  It's quick, dirty and cheap fun. Why not?
I love this game the gameplay is amazing but the story is kinda ♥♥♥♥ but its still awesome.
FUN and Awesome. Not as awesome as Prototype 1 where it was really killing and ♥♥♥♥, this is more stealth and crap.
The game itself is fun. However I cannot save. It said that 'Failed to save data' .

One of the best open-world third-person view action games! While the story may look ridiculous, it's actually doesn't matter. The storyline is like a good old-fashioned  trash  movie, while the gameplay... that is what it's all about!  Love the game engine - all in one - AI, physics, graphics (game looks yummy even on my low-end videocard) - great. The setting is also a strong part of the game. I did not played the first game, so for me it was a nice surprise. It's like   Resident Evil   except   YOU   are the Biohazard here.  Pretty damn nice, 9.6/10

I barely got through the prologue before i saw what people were complaining about. i have an R9 raideon graphics card, well above needed specs, and the framerate dropped to about 3fps. that is just unacceptable, period.

Amazing game i completed it in two days with 18 hours total gaming. i would recomend this to people with gaming computers as at an average im running at 2 fps on a good computer. Putting lag aside the game is one of the best ive played and i would rate it easily 9/10, but because of the large quantity of lag that many such as i have been experienceing i would have to rate this game 6/10 it may sound harsh but it did ruin the gaming experience I had.
nice fly around game...jump here n there

Sooo Angry!  Prototype 2 is an awesome game, but not for the faint-hearted. With incredibly rude language and brutal excecutions, this game will linger for a while. I only had a problem with the graphics, but that is just my computer. Other than that, this is an incredibly brutal game, with a lot of blood, but not unrealistic.

Another very fun sequel to the previous game. If you enjoyed the first then you'll love this game, with slightly improved controls, fun powers which can be upgraded and if you just generally enjoy to mess things up supremely, then this game is for you.  My only quarrels lie in the fact that we play as Sgt.Heller, which although I think he's a great character, the plot could have been improved to have been about playing as Mercer again, since everyone loves him so much, however if you can see past that, you should enjoy the game!

Great game if you like prototype 1
is it cool game i love jump and speed , zombie , soldier

Finished (did the last main mission) after 28 hours. These were ca. 23 pure fun, blood, action and carnage. And the last 5 hours PURE frustration. The last mission.  This really bad last mission which kills all the fun you had all that time. If you would just play the mission without dying, it would be, don't know 15 minutes. It took me 5 hours to beat the END BOSS. ♥♥♥♥ it!  Until then, I had a main stories, some side stories, action without end and the feeling that I am the overpowered king of the city. At least until 3 infected or 4 attack helicopters or worse, all at the same time came at me. Then it would become even more hectic and fun. And sometimes I died... in the beginning.  You get more and more powers, but not so many that you get confused. A lot of your upgrades are passive ones or only useable in certain situations,  like destroy tank with one attack, or do that attack 75% faster or  run x% faster or have more health or have more 'hounds' in your pack.  All updates are useful somehow, you can take enemy helicopters after a while and just use them or glide around the city and do attacks from above or ignore the main story and have fun.  The game did not crash once in these 28 hours. And I do not have a special computer.: Processor Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Quad CPU Q9550 @ 2.83GHz, 2832 Mhz, 4 Core(s), 4 Logical Processor(s) Name NVIDIA GeForce GTX 660 Ti 8 GB RAM  I was able to run it with max details and no fps problems at all.  The game is easier than the first one, which is somehow a nice thing. You had a lot more moving and fighting options in the first one, which was nice too.  However, if you want fun and blood, then this is a very good game. If you can beat the last enemy in half an hour, then you are a semi god at least :)  Really good game, way too hard last enemy. Buy it anyways!
Dont usually play a game multiple times but I went through campaign 3 times on this game.   Consume citizens to save citizens.  10/10 would kill humanity again

Well, i will be brief. Prototype 2 is the sequel to Prototype (1). On my opinion its good game. Brutal, action adventure where you can upgrade your character and his incredible skills. Open world in destroyed New York..Arhhh..YES..It is actually good environment for myself. Lot of people say that have boring campain. Yes, for begginer this can be 'nothing much'. I am fan of this series, but it has some 'errors'. P2 giving new and new abilities and ways how kill someone with STYLE, but lot of these just lost. I liked in P1 feeling, i was an original. In P2 developers made lot of mistakes and P2 is story about 'stupid superhumans' with 'SAME' (always easy to kill them) skills. Yes, P2 has very easy difficulty, something is happening on HARD or INSANE diff....But i still LOVE this game and this little 'errors' don't make me to hate this game.. I really recommending this game. <3  + grafic + gameplay + quite creative + environment and size of map  + character  - enemies - difficulty - some missions ( just hunt and then consume or kill your target) - length of story, you can finish story in 4-5 hours (without bonus missions)  MY REVIEW - 8/10

CON  I'm not a huge fan of games where they tell you whom to play. That said, that's my main grudge against P2 -- you can't really choose what your character looks like, what his backstory is, etc. etc., and the fact that like in P1, it isn't really anyone too likeable doesn't help.  The control scheme now lets you choose two active powers versus Prototype 1's one, and while that sounds nice (especially the option to assign a slow move and a fast move, or a close range one and a long-range / area one), I didn't really find it all that useful in the game (I would assign one fast, close range attack as primary power and use it 95 % of the time, and have something like tendrils -- or later whip fist -- as a secondary for the rare cases where I needed to attack a helicopter or needed an area effect. Using each roughly 50 % for great synergy? Not so much. But maybe, that was just me.). The downside is that while you get twice as many active skills, you have to handle them with the same number of buttons on the controller, and the controls feel less precise than in P1. Ironically, the most annoying issue wasn't even attack related; if you don't get quite the right attack, but still an attack, it's usually non-catastrophic. What I did get often enough for it to be a nuisance however was being on a stealth mission, pressing (B) to interact with some hapless soldier (usually to consume them and gain their memories; sometimes just to stop him keeping an eye on the person you came for), and instead prying lose some feature of the landscape that also happened to be close (but didn't even necessarily look like you could interact with it). And well, prying lose random ACs or oiltanks or whatever automatically raises an alert and ruins the stealth part of your mission. (This can also be an issue during melee, where you get a prompt to press (B) to consume an enemy who's been weakened enough, but who may die soon, and where in crowded locations (B) will then often select bystanders seemingly at random, all while your actual target is bleeding out.  I liked the skill system in P1 better (get XP for everything, then once you have enough XP to improve whatever skill you're interested in (i.e. buy many minor things quickly, or save up for big improvements)) vs P2's 'you'll level up again at so-and-so many XP, and every time you do, you can improve exactly one skill', but in the end, it wasn't a huge factor. (That said, the thing where you can get a skill buy eating the brain of someone who has it still exists.)  PRO  Unsurprisingly, the city looks much better than in P1; the player character looks much better, the voice acting is decent this time, and most of all, while there are certainly repetitive elements (mostly the Blacknet assassinations, which often don't have much in the way of plot -- this is even lampshaded one time: 'So this guy is an APC driver? Doesn't really sound like a big bad mover and shaker ... ah, whatever, I'll kill him anyway.'), the game, especially the main quest, feels much more like a story than the first game did at the best of times, and a sense of urgency is upheld at (almost) all times. Like a soap opera or Baking Bread, it isn't necessarily the cleverest plot on earth, but each mission creates enough of a cliffhanger to make you wonder what will happen next, and it's tremendously easy to get sucked into 'just one more mission before bed.'  As a bonus, much of the optional 'color' of the setting is now told through audio logs you can find (and listen to while you move along), rather than flickering memories with corny visuals that don't really blend with the rest of the game and that interrupt your flow like in P1. Small change, surprisingly big effect. (Technically I guess they're a cross between the landmark orbs and the 'color' memories of P1, but I played P1 and P2 in the same week, so it's becoming a bit of a blur.)  There are challenges and mini-games and somewhat repetitive kill zones, but unlike in Saints Row IV, they're not mandatory -- you can do one once in a while for variety or XP, or do them after the main quest for something to do with your then near maxed-out powers. Or, you can ignore them completely, and just do the main quest. Your choice.  The gliding, especially once upgraded, still won't carry you as far as SR IV's, but it feels world's away from P1's, which never felt much better than plain old falling.  A big plus: Starting maybe 2/3 in, P1 would just try to overwhelm you -- gliding was practically useless, perhaps in an attempt to keep you at street level, and at street level, there'd be a constant barrage -- even if for once, zombies weren't attacking you and soldiers weren't detecting you, you'd frequently ragdoll all over the place simply for getting caught in random crossfire of the marines or blackwatch using tanks and rockets at street level. Yes, it sounds good on paper -- getting swarmed is obviously very much a zombie trope, and the careless use of artillery demonstrated desperation / casual disregard for any survivors, but in reality, it just makes for a really unfun game mechanic when the true challenge of a misison isn't Doing The Thing, but getting there to do the thing. Meh. (This was exacerbated by the fact that using any speed powers could get a strike team called on you.) In P2, you get caught in the cross fire much less easily, you don't get swarmed by the zombies as much, strike teams aren't called in as easily, take longer to arrive, are easier to shake off, and are easier to kill. Heck, it's almost too easy in P2, but I'll take that over P1's traversing the city being a chore any day. P2 has 'joy of movement!' :)  RECOMMENDATION  If you can stomach playing a character that they picked, rather than one that you picked, give it a go, especially if you've played part one, but get it while it's on sale. (It seems pretty much too late to vote with your dollar anyway, now that they've already downsized Radical -- which is actually a shame, I would've been interested in seeing how a Prototype 3 would've come out.)
AMD Radeon R9 290X 4GB, i7 4790k, 8 GB RAM, running on a SSD (so well above the recommended sys req): 720p, medium settings -> under 30FPS. I run Metro on high with max settings at 1080p 60 fps.
Piece of total garbage. Doesnt run for longer than 40 seconds and is buggy as hell within those 40 seconds. Steam. Actually do your job and look at if the game works before making it available.

I enjoyed this game more than I thought I would. However I did have that glitch early in the game that required me to set my CPU to one core in order to move on in the story, but quickly changed it back to all 4 cores.  The 10 hour single player game is worth the price if you like Third Person open world action games. The game ran smooth with 50+ monsters, helicopters, tanks, soldiers, and stuff flying everywhere. Running around, flying, and parkour all was smooth/fun.  You can pick up guns, do side quests to beef up your char, or just cause massive damage to an area. It has a bit of stealth as well, but mostly not required. The story is just your typical - Rough tough good guy smashing bad guys and getting tricked along the way, but every hour or so you get a new method of attacking and killing so I kept rolling forward.  If you want a GTA Meets Superman, but with Zombies/Monsters/Big Cities then this is the game for you. Just don't expect anything more than a fun smash and bash action game.  Would play again if I didn't have so many other games to play.

Prototype 2 is the typical lackluster sequel if there ever was one. Sure, the graphics are prettier and the gameplay is 'refined', but it suffers the burden of being not only a poor port, but something of a shoe-in title.   The story is less than great and won't keep you invested in the game. While the game itself is fun, it has the potential to be extremely tedious and sometimes purely boring. The 'side missions' are a rinse and repeat formula and strikingly exhausting. Sure, the first few are fun, maybe - but soon they become a real pain.   If you're playing the game with an AMD card, you'll have to deal with constant memory leakage, gradually cranking the game's performance down and leaving you with a sad twitching pile of polygons and laggy blur effects. I had to end up downloading a third party application to have the game run smooth and actually have a chance at finishing it without losing my mind.   If you're interested in an 'open world' superhero game, (the open world is actually not 'open' - it's split into districts of fairly small sizes that require fast travel between them; invisible walls, ahoy!) where you're free to run wild and destroy things and throw people, this game is exactly what you're looking for. If you're looking for immersive story and impressive mechanics, steer clear.

I don't understand why this game has mixed reviews. I played this game on console for many hours, so I know what I'm talking about, I just recently got it on pc though.   Not only is this game extremely fun and there are endless ways to take out enemies, you literally feel like you're unstoppable. You get many upgrades to your character, new weapons, and a pretty good story. It's extremely gory, so people who like gory games, this is for you. Even when you finish the game, you can still play it and have a good time. Also a good game to play if you're angry lol.   I guess the one thing I could say that makes this game negative, is it is really easy. Some might like that, but some others like a challenge when they play, and even on the normal difficulty, difficulties definitely don't surpass the easy parts. Again, some might like it, some might not. Depends on what kind of player you are.   Overall: 8.5/10.
an amazing;y fun game with interesting story, that blast's it proseser out of the water.
Now this is a bugfest! DO NOT BUY!!! On the first mission you have to manually set the game to use only one core(CPU) to progress in the campaign. -!♥♥♥♥♥ GAEM!-
Love it. Total blast to play. Definitely has some technical problems which is disappointing, but I was able to work around them.

Don't buy this game. It's just full of bugs. I can't get past one of the first missions, the game crashes during the loading and there is apparently no fix for that specific bug. There are several other glitches that will make your game crash. Ultimately, I think it's kinda rare that someone succeeded in finishing the game. I read everywhere that it's just a very, very bad console port and that there is absolutely no support in case of problems with the game. I regret buying this game.  Edit : Bought a new computer with an nvidia graphics card and the game worked lke a charm. However, because of my past experience, I still can't recommend the game. The game is kinda fun but doesn't add anything to the first. In fact, if you played the first and liked it, you don't even need to play prototype 2...it's pretty much the same but less original. The final fight and the ending leave a feeling of...'I did all this just for that??????'.

Another great Prototype game from Radical Entertainment/Activision. In fact, many people have negative views on this game, probably because of some repetitive missions and the fact that Alex Mercer is not really depicted as a good guy in general. But many of bad reviews seem to come from those people who do not know how to play games like this.  Now, I am not sure if I can just boldly say that Prototype 2 is any inferior to the prequel. In my honest opinion, Prototype 2 was just as good, if not better. There are many missions that make you infiltrate the facilities and consume people and such (Actually, pretty much most of missions are like that) and I guess people might find this rather boring. But in my opinion, I liked the fact that the game was focusing more on the story, rather than action in general. This, does not mean the game is boring at all.  As for the action part, well, the game is certainly easier than the first Prototype. When the first one makes you get real busy with your controller (or keyboard and mouse), I didn't think the second one was like that in general. But this doesn't mean you can just sit back and relax, you still better buckle down, especially the final boss fight. I kind of do not like how the upgrade system changed in this game....I wish I could just buy whatever the upgrade I want to buy if I can afford like I could in the first one. But well, I wouldn't say this is a deal-breaker.   Overall, fun game. Even though I can not really approve the ending and all, as an action game, it is one heck of a ride.   9.8/10

I cannot play this game, I'm mostly just writing this to let others know that this is a ♥♥♥♥ port. Stay away from this on PC, avoid it like it has the plague. I honestly would love a refund for my money, and time spent trying to fix something that should have already been fixed.  Edit: I did get this to start working with my AMD card, there is a wonderful topic in the discussion board that helped, but that still does not change the fact that I would not recommend buying this on a PC, it crashes frequently, and I've had sound cut out on cutscenes at odd times.  As for the game itself the story is actually pretty decent, the game is more of the same of prototype so it is fun at times, but the combat feels lacking compared to the first one, this is partially due to having two powers out at once now, and one button is used for either power.  Overall I would say it's average for fun, but if you did kind of enjoy the plot of prototype, I did, then this is not a must play immediately but I say an eventually, like you know three years later.
Quite possibly one of the most broken ports of a game ever released. Great job you sure did it!

Completely unplayable me, as it locks up almost immediately after starting, even after trying all the possible fixes shared in the forum and elsewhere online. Unfortunately for me, I bought it from Humble, so I can't refund. Everyone who's able to play it seems to love it, but if you're going to take a chance on it, buy it directly from Steam so you can get your money back if it doesn't work.
I like it, It's fun.

I was happy to get this game at first till I started playing it. First thing I always do before starting a game is go into options. That section of the game was broken right of the bat. I wanted to select screen resolution and check key bindings. None of this was possible. Started the game I quickly found out when it said use left mouse botton only, the right botton worked. Then when the game said to use right button to siphon life and restore health, no button anyplace on the keyboard or mouse worked. The game was stuck. I had to alt + delete to quit the game. Did some google searching and found lots of issues with this game starting with non Nvidia Gfx cards to changeing mouse configurations. Meeting the system requirements fully, this should not happen. So I take my thumbs up on this game back and warn others. This game is not worth buying.
Prototype 2 is a massive upgrade from Prototype. Smoother gameplay, improved combat, a more organized system of upgrading, and amped up graphics (no more odd looking cars).

To people not familiar with Prototype 1, I recommend it, it's a power fantasy and a lot of fun. There are references to the first game but it's not needed to have a fun time. This game is a Power Fantasy and it does that in spades, you feel powerful. Enjoy. My review below is for people who have played and enjoyed the plot and storyline of the original Prototype.   To fans of the original Prototype, this game is about the same. It's a big more organized, with a bit more work put into it. But it has the same progression and feels very much like you are just playing the original Prototype with a few extras added in. If you feel a 'Prototype itch' this may be a decent game to pick up if it was heavily discounted, but I generally do not recommend this game. I do not recommend it because the completion of this game left a bad taste in my mouth. I enjoyed the original Protoype, and loved the story and the plot. But this game throws it all away. Because (Spoilers)    Alex Mercer, the original protagonist, is rewritten as a batshit crazy idiot-ball carrying villian who actively pursues the very thing you fought to stop in the original game. Which, as someone who played the first Prototype who enjoyed and got to understand the complex personality of Alex Mercer, I find to be a complete cop-out, and this just thoroughly destroyed my enjoyment of the Prototype franchise.

very good game to play meanwhile you are waiting for dota actulization

This game is fun when it works. Unfortunately, it needed to be tested against AMD hardware, and wasn't. Also it has received virtually zero support from the publisher or developers. It has a known memory leak that causes it to crash after some period of play, issues with resolution, and unpredictable framerates.  However, the game itself is pretty cool. I enjoyed playing it, as much as I was able to. It's unfortunate that it wasn't handled better. Maybe someday it'll be patched, but I don't expect it.
they should really fix the lag in the game

CAUTION:  I've played this game on my PS3 and it had a very fun storyline, so once I saw it at a bargain price during the 2015 Summer Sale I decided to purchase it to relive a very great game. However, I was wrong. I'm running above recommended PC specifications and I'm struggling to get a solid 20FPS on ultra low. After reading through a few other reviews it seems that a lot of other users are experiencing issues as well; namely AMD systems.

First of all let me start off this review by stating the the game shipped broken and was never fixed. It always had a bad memory leak and certain missions would cause it to crash. But now since the Omega Drivers release from AMD and the subsequent upgrade to Windows 10 it is time to remove this game from Steam.  The game is completely broken. Under Win 8.1 and the AMD 14.2 drivers you could mostly play until the memory leak ended your fun. If you decide to run an older OS and even older drivers, you can have fun in the game. Really it's not a bad game and at times is quite fun! On a scale of 1 - 100 I would give it a solid 65 with the memory leak lowering the score to 57.  Under Windows 10 the game will actually start, but then the memory leak ends the fun after 5 minutes. Everyone is going to upgrade to Windows 10 for DX12 games. Thus this game is completely dead.  Please Valve remove this game from the Steam Store. There is no reason to leave abandoned games on your storefront. I wish Activision had allowed the original development team to patch the game, but alas that's the current state of PC development I suppose. Release, promote, and run.
Do not buy this game, it crashes every 30-60 with newer graphics cards. Avoid at all costs.
Game crashes on launch. There is no known fix that works for me and this product is useless. This shouldn't even be for sale, ESPECIALLY at $40.

Can't recommend this, unfortunately. After installing, I first had to spend about 1,5 hours trying to get the game to run beyond the intro (which was, admittedly, awesome). I finally managed to solve the problem with help from others in the forums and eagerly sat down to play.  I uninstalled the game after 45 minutes of play time.   I loved the original Prototype because of the way that its story was told and because the factions involved (Blackwatch specifically) were interesting. Not dog-kickingly evil, but clearly not nice, either - just trying to prevent the spread. The gameplay was lots of fun too, but that wasn't what led me to get Prototype 2. If you are all about the gameplay, this review might not apply to you.  In the short span of time I played, I was dismayed to find that the interesting-seeming protagonist was, in fact, a violent and stupid thug with no redeeming qualities, easily led and manipulated. The game's villain was apparent right from the start and was all but moustache-twirlingly evil. Blackwatch appears to have become an organization of deathly stupid dog-kicking nazis who (minor spoiler) release infected into 'test areas' apparently just for the fun of it.   The open-world gameplay didn't work for me either; I found the city area cluttered and overly full. The new look works and it makes sense to have people sleeping rough etc., but I missed the clear lines of the first game. The control change for gliding and airdash REALLY annoyed me as well, especially as I had replayed the entire first game and scored platinum on all movement events for the fun of it just before starting the second. I loved the way movement flowed in the first game and it just seemed completely unnecessary to change it in the second.   Some of the mechanics seemed promising (consuming specific evolved to gain certain powers, etc.), but all in all, the cartoonish 'villains' and idiot unsympathetic protagonist killed this game for me very quickly. What a shame.

COMPLETED 100%  Prototype 2 quite feels like a dumbed down version of Prototype 1 and is impeded by a lack of challenge in both enemies and gameplay structure.  The story is pretty straightforward in this sequel and really nothing to be excited about. As advertised, you play as Venom... I mean Heller this time. A former marine who gets powers from the MC of the first game, Mercer. Eventually they both clash when Heller realizes who the real bad guy is. And that's pretty much how the game boils down to. Missions have taken a step backwards as disguising plays a more important role and you'll find yourself infiltrating enemy bases far more often. It could have been a good thing, if not for the fact that the devs doesnt seem to put much effort into this. The stealth aspect in this game is honestly, laughable. Marred by incredibly dumb AI that's beyond ridiculous. Soldiers see you flying in the air? Jump 100 feet in the air and drop right down? Nope, nothing out of the ordinary. See the infamous James Heller walking right in front of their face? Nope, they just see you as a regular civilian. But do something as small as jump over a table or hop over a comrade? Everyone suddenly goes into red alert.  You don't even to silently consume people if you don't want to. Just grab the guy, consume him, jump over a fence, transform, jump back into the base 10 seconds later and everyone acts like nothing happened at all! The world of P2 is fairly large but is now divided into three separate areas: Red, Yellow, and Green Zone. Each having a different nature and scale of infestation, thus providing for some fresh scenes for free roaming. On the other hand there's only 3 kinds of interiors you'll ever enter in the entire game, and that's military bases, labs and infested lairs. Most of which are just copy+paste in appearance. Missions are where the game tends to get slightly repetitive, particularly in side missions. Find this, kill that, find that, destroy this. There's not much variety in what you do apart from causing destruction and mayhem everywhere you go. That's where the action comes in; it's still fun slicing up enemies and covering the streets in blood and gore. But it's too simple, because the game is that easy. Even worse, you have significantly less attack moves and powers to use, as compared to what the first game offered, which is another disappointment. Prototype 2 suffers terribly from many shortcomings but is still the same old enjoyable fun you can get for an open world title. Sadly not much of an improvement from the first game, if not, at all.  PROS: - The Red Zone is pretty awesome in scale and magnitude - Venom/Carnage simulator - Blood. So much blood and gore. And explosions. Lovely.  CONS: - A few power moves stripped down or removed from the first game - The same old Manhatten open world is nothing new - Sh*t AI stealth mechanics; escaping from an alarm or strike team is like a walk in the park - Too easy to beat - Game is very badly optimized for AMD cards. Forced enable mouse acceleration is another pain in the ♥♥♥.

Prototype 2 is an especially good action game where you play the role of sergeant Heller with lethal surpernatural shape-shifting abilities given by Alex Mercer. During the game Heller wants her daughter back and to stop Balckwatch and Mercer from destroying New York. Missions are excellent and contain a lot of fight against Mercer's creatures and Blackwatch elite troopers. You can consume almost everybody to gain health and to obtin memories that help you to understand better the story. In the city you can find collectibles to be found and liars to be cleared for mutators as a reward. Mutators give you superpowers and you can earn XP points by completing missions. As you level up you can open and obtain upgrades that make Heller more deadlier and give you advantage during the gameplay. The game ends with an epic fight against your creator, Alex Mercer. Prototype 2 has the 'Radnet Access' pack dlc that gives you 5 unique abilities and 50+ challenges to complete. 8/10

Yes, it's even simpler, just one button to attack. Forget combos, it's just mash X, press A, mash X.  While in the previous game you obtained your powers and upgrades through simply playing the game, more emphasis is now put on playing the mini-games which completely break immersion in the already weak story.  If you enjoy playing mini-games and searches for collectibles then you will enjoy this game. If you enjoy open sand boxes that you can just run around in and cause general mayhem then you will have fun. If you are looking for a good story, then look for another game in my opinion.

Prototype two was a good hack n slash. The graphics were nice and the animation was fluid. The part I liked best was the open sandbox world which could be explored and I could just start mayhem at any given time. The enemy gradually becomes stronger as the game goes on and it's interesting to watch how the city deteriates through gameplay.  Another cool thing is that I didn't need to play the first one to understand number 2. They even have optional recap you can watch about the previous game, but Prototype 2 has it's own story that doesn't really depend on the first.   Challenge mode was fun too, I found myself spending a good hour on one challenge trying to achieve a gold award.   I didn't finish this game though, perhaps I will later. I ended up losing interest after about 12 hours of gameplay because the story isn't really that in depth. You can tell they tried though, just not a lot of meat to the storyline so to speak and running around brutally murdering crowds of people gets old after awhile.   Overall I give this game 6 out of 10 MF Falco's.

If you like sandbox games then you'll love this as it is so addictive.  The first Prototype was fun but ultimately repetitive such that I got bored of it less than half-way through. This sequel takes everything that was enjoyable about the original game, i.e. the cool power-ups and mayhem you could cause with them, but manages to maintain the interest for much longer, thanks to constant rewards and more variety in the missions. Add in Challenge modes and collectibles and you have one fun game that might not win many Game of the Year awards come the turn of 2012 but will definitely be one of your favourites nevertheless. I guarantee it.  Graphics are an improvement on the PS2-era visuals of the original and the engine does a fine job of handling dozens of enemies and explosions on the screen at once. I especially love the way that the game shows a scene from the game running behind the main menu and as soon as you select Continue it jumps straight into the game... no loading at all!

I found this game, while deeply enjoyable, to be not quite as good as the original, and I'm having trouble figuring out why. The characters are more interesting, the gameplay is more intuitive, the visual asthetic delivers the feel of a city truly experiencing a disaster of this level where the first game failed in that regard. I suppose that my real problem is that Heller feels invincible, while Mercer felt very vulnerable in the first - and he survived a nuclear warhead from a few meters away. The sandbox is smaller, the new enemies feel a little tacked on, and none of the bosses really inspire that gut wrenching terror that you got in the original Prototype (none of them made me want to toss my computer out the window either, and the first game definately brought me to that precipice).  All in all, it really delivers a long, fulfilling and well rounded experience. Oh yeah, and you can rip a tank in half with your bare hands if you level your character right.

Prototype 2 is a free roam hack n slash adventure revolving around the story of Sgt. James Heller who was turned into what's known as an 'Evolved' by Prototype 1's protagonist, Alex Mercer. As you progress through the game, Heller learns of the horrors that Mercer has wished to cause, ultimately having a plan for the whole of humanity with malicious intent.  Apart from the story, the game is honestly relatively the same as that of Prototype. The only differences being that Heller has a fifth power known as Tendrils and has the ability to summon Brawlers (a medium-sized infected monster) varying between 2-4 to aid him in combat. The game itself offers only a scant amount of enemy variety from that of the first game, adding in only four new enemies, Juggernauts, Goliaths, Flyers (can't remember if they have an actual codename or if that is their actual codename, but they're pretty much just infected birds), and Evolved.  When Evolved were introduced as an enemy in the game, I myself was personally excited. 'To be fighting against those with similar powers to mine, damn what a refreshing experience!' Unfortunately, I was only like that for the first few Evolved units I fought. After the third one went down, I realized that they all had the same attack pattern, same dodge and attack qte, and generally the same weapon types. There were only a few times where evolved were different, and that was when you encountered Evolved with the Pack Leader and Whipfist abilities, to which you simply beat their face in and consumed them promptly, attaing their respective powers. The fact that they didn't give any extra variety to these guys was staggering, and honestly kinda saddening. I would have loved to have fought off Evolved trying to slice me up to bits with Claws or the Blade power, or dodge out of the way when an Evolved would try to pummle me with Hammerfist. Unfortunately, everyone had little bitty sword hands. It may have been stated at some point that others don't have the ability to maintain advanced forms due to their genetic make-up, but at least give us some different forms of combat.  Aside from the bad enemy variety, everything else was alright. The story developed in a good Prototype fashion, there are collectibles and side missions aplenty, and a new perk system that allowed the player to have more variety with how they went about playing their James Heller.   If you aren't a hardcore Protoype fan but are a fan of hack n slash games, I'd suggest waiting for this game to go on sale for $10 maybe $15. The game offers a decent 10 hour single-player experience (this of course means not collecting everything) and is an alright grab for a low price.  7/10

I loved the first Prototype, I even bought Prototype 2's collector's edition for Xbox 360. It's sitting on a shelf above my head right now. This is a fun game, no doubt about that. Once you actually gain all your powers, you start to feel like a god, but the game has a natural progression. You start with your fists, gain a power, gain more power, until you can stand up to your maker. My only gripe is where Alex Mercer from the first game felt like a depressed teen with super powers, Heller feels so angry that I expect him to turn into the Hulk so I can play Ultimate Destruction. Literally every line from him is '..♥♥♥♥...' '♥♥♥♥♥' '♥♥♥♥' 'swear word'. I understand his family was taken from him, and that is one of the most traggic things in a person's life is when your family is killed. But, seriously? Almost every line? I can't fault the game in its gameplay as the devs really took care of what they worked on, but Heller felt overly angry at everything. A character who is a part of Mercer's 'evolved' *spoilers I guess* is helping Heller from inside Gentek to try and bring down Mercer as she's in it for herself. All Heller does is say 'you got me intel that could get you turned into goop or experimented like a lab rat? ♥♥♥♥♥, get more!' At least try and be a bit more friendly to the only Evolved who seems to be on your side, is in a very advantageous position and in a way you could spot for miles away betray you at the end to get into Mercer's good graces.   The soundtrack is great, offering some very emotional and slow melodies or fast paced tracks that really feel like this is something to be hyped over. The voice acting is also very good, hitting the right marks as you do feel for these characters, but Heller sounds like he's Bruce Banner from 'The Avengers' where he reveals that he's always angry, but he shows it all the time.  In closing, I'd say if you weren't a fan of the previous one, then this is a pass, but if you're like me and loved the first one, then this is a buy. Just remember though, Heller does tend to swear in almost every sentence, I think Prototype 2 beat '♥♥♥♥- a documentary on the word' for amount of times he said '♥♥♥♥.'

I am usually not a fan of parkour-based FPS games, as they often require a lot of coordination. Nevertheless, this game is different than games like Dying Light as far as parkour, which is a breeze in Prototype 2. The RADNET DLC is a must-have for more casual gamers given the incredible abilities it can provide.  There is certainly a storyline, though it is rather predictable. Nevertheless, I find the gameplay is absolutely amazing and I reallly enjoy the destruction one can create on such a massive scale! As far as the original Prototype, I played it for a bit, but personally I feel Prototype 2 has a richness the original lacks.  Nonetheless, that is simply my personal opinion. Being an older and more casual gamer, I tend to gravitate towards games with difficulties that can be more easily scaled like this one. After only a day of playing, I knew this would end up on my 'Favorites' list.

TL; DR: PURE RAGE. Consume and destroy. Glorious catharsis.  PROTOTYPE 2: MEAT IS MURDER. You are the meat, and you are the murder.  The goal is rampage, and Prototype 2 delivers, mixing smooth stealth infiltration with fast-paced combat drenched in blood and power. Your enemies are cartoonish caricatures of evil, because they would HAVE TO BE to deserve your meat-monster wrath as you slash them limb from limb and devour their bodies. You are The Incredible Hulk, you are Carnage, you are also The Punisher.  It's not a hard game. You're more than a match for your enemies and checkpoints are generously dispersed. Some of the more obnoxious elements from the first game have either been toned down (super-soldiers no longer require a GoW-style QTE to not die to) or removed entirely (no virus-scanning drones).  The story is told in epileptic, edgy montages. You are James Heller, family man and hardass soldier who has lost his wife and daughter in the second outbreak of the so-called Mercer Virus, believed to be spread by Alex Mercer, hero(?) of the first Prototype. James is infected by Mercer with the power to kill and eat everyone, which sends him on a quest of consuming vengeance.   Prototype 2 is an overall smaller game than the first Prototype. The city is split up into three compact districts. The morass of point-buy powers has been replaced by a steady trickle of upgrades from doing side quests and finding collectibles. Backstory nuggets are delivered through a collection of easily found black boxes strewn throughout the city rather than buried in a sprawling story web of random people's brains. This works to its benefit, as no one part of the game overstays its welcome, and in the first game everything did.  It's a fine example of a compact XBox 360-era action game, and an excellent outlet for your constant building anger. You are angry all the time now, right? Right? Is it just me?
